item.title: RAND
item.description: RAND Experiment to check effects of health insurance subsidies. In short, subsidized public health insurance should not be expected to yield a dramatic health dividend.

item.title: randomized trials
item.description: Randomized Trials When analyzing data form a randomized trial or any other research design, masters almost always begin with a check on whether treatment and control groups indeed look similar.

item.title: Regression Discontinuity
item.description: Regression Discontinuity People just above the thresh-hold get treated, and the people just below do not get treated. There is an arbitrary cut-off.

item.title: Selection Bias
item.description: Selection Bias This is based on the book mastering metrics 1 chapter and is explained with a health insurance example.

item.title: Show Me the Numbers - Book notes
item.description: Show Me the Numbers - Book Notes A book about how to best display numbers. This is closely related to #visual-analytics #cis5250.

item.title: The Oregon Trail
item.description: The Oregon Trail Lottery in Oregon in 2008 where applicants could have a chance to win Health insurance. It was aimed at a special group of people (think low income Americans), and applicants won a chance to apply for the insurance.

item.description: Week 3 The Economic Model & Understanding Evidence [[The Oregon Trail]]

item.title: Week 8 Race, Policing, and Criminal Justice
item.description: Week 8 Race, Policing, and Criminal Justice Economist flair on controvertial topics such as Race, policing, and criminal justice. Rolen firear, big microeconomist from harvard.
